section.title: Overview
section.para: As an administrator at a bank, you use the Jurisdiction Maintenance module to define the roles used in and the authorisation matrix used to release transactional reporting messages to the customers.

Jurisdiction defines the maximum amount of money that your users are authorised to submit a transaction for. You can assign combination of roles and permissions to your users, which allows them to perform transactions on permitted products and for a set amount. If a user does not have sufficient privileges for submitting a transaction, another user with the necessary privileges can submit the transaction.

For transactions in trade, you can set the authorisation matrix for your users, permitting them to use products or sub products with the tenor and maximum amount limit configured. For example, you can set up the authorisation matrix for an Issued Banker's Guarantee (BG) for events such as New, Amend, or Message, for a specific amount and tenor (period). The following illustration is an example for a authorisation matrix setup:
The authorisation matrix can be set up for issuance, amendment, message, and also if it is of multiple levels authorisation, can be sequential or non sequential.

For higher transaction amounts, or more hierarchical company organisations, the maximum amount can also be defined for a combination of two roles. In such a case the transaction must first be checked by a user with a controller profile (role 1), and then signed by a user with a sign profile (role 2). This authorisation jurisdiction system can therefore force a validation by two users as well as the input user (known as a six-eyes validation).

The authorisation amounts are expressed in the company's base currency. Whenever a transaction is submitted, a middle rate conversion is used to compare the transaction amount with these maximum authorisation amounts. The rates are fetched from the 's rate table.
As a reminder, two main categories of roles should be highlighted:

listitem.para: Some roles will be used internally within the bank, being granted only to the bank middle-office users.
Other roles will be made available to each client company; the company will in turn grant them to their users, according to the jurisdiction they want to set up.

note.para: A bank group may decide to set up all the roles later used by its banks and their client companies. Even though this approach may look restrictive, a standardisation of the roles is highly recommended, since it both speeds up the creation of user accounts and client companies in , and simplifies the tasks and understanding at the bank level.

section.title: Jurisdiction Maintenance - Navigation
section.para: To navigate to the Jurisdiction Maintenance function, from the toolbar, select System Features from the home page, then select Jurisdiction Maintenance from the left side navigation menu.

section.title: Jurisdiction Maintenance - Options
section.para: The Jurisdiction Maintenance options are part of the System Features menu. They are as follows:

listitem.para: Assign local names to the roles created by the bank, in order to match your company's own naming conventions and facilitate further administration tasks. View and modify roles, a role being a set of basic permissions that can be grouped according to the various needs.
Define the properties of each role, overriding the properties defined for it by the bank. You can set limits to the amount that users with particular roles are allowed to process.

section.title: Jurisdiction Maintenance - Roles
section.para: This option allows a Bank Administrator to assign local names to the roles created by the bank.

When you select this option, you are presented with a list of all the roles the company can use and their descriptions. Click the Search Options link to display the fields that can be used to filter the list. You can use Reference, Status and Actor fields at the top of the page.

note.para: Only the Reference column is available if maker-checker functionality is not enabled.

section.para:
You can view a role by clicking the View
icon in the right-hand column. If you are a bank group administrator, you can edit it by clicking the Edit
icon in the right-hand column, or delete it by clicking the Delete
icon (Special privileges are required to see the delete option). A last column is showing the various actions that can be undertaken in order to display, alter or delete each role record.
Edit and Add display the same form, but in the case of Edit it is preset with the existing details of the role. After entering the details, click Submit at the bottom of the form.

note.para: The role name uniquely identifies a role, so two roles cannot have the same name. Also take care that if a role is attributed to multiple banks, they will share it, and any role modification should therefore be handled with special care by the banks since it potentially affects all the related branches.

section.para: When a role is modified, all users granted this role will automatically get or lose the added or removed permissions the next time they log in. This is an interesting aspect of the use of roles and profiles: there is no need to update all users individually when a profile has to be amended.

section.title: Jurisdiction Maintenance - Authorisation
section.para: You can define the properties for each role from this page. When you select this option, you are presented with a list of all the authorisations defined in the system. The following section describes the authorisation matrix.

When a transaction is received, a bank user is required to review, approve or reject, and process it. After selecting the appropriate options, and the Submit button is clicked, the Authorisation Matrix is checked for rules that apply to the transaction. The system will check product codes, types, authorisations levels and amounts defined in each rule, to see if the rule matches the transaction.

note.para: All rules will be checked, and if any that match the transaction (and the user privilege and authority levels) are satisfied, the transaction will be submitted and the transaction will be submitted and sent to the bank for processing. If no rules are satisfied, the transaction is placed in a "Pending Authorise" state until a authorised user attempts to submit it.

section.para: You can search the list by entering search criteria in the Product, Sub Product, Status and Actor fields at the top of the page.
